title: 110_hr5646
content: The Act titled "Protecting the Second Amendment and Hunting Rights on Federal Lands Act of 2008" allows for possessing or carrying firearms and ammunition in units of the National Park System and the National Wildlife Refuge System. The Act "Protecting the Second Amendment and Hunting Rights on Federal Lands Act of 2008" acknowledges the second amendment right to bear arms and highlights the use of firearms for self-defense in the United States. It also mentions the positive impact of legislation expanding residents' rights to use firearms for self-defense on reducing firearm-related crime. Additionally, it points out that Federal regulations currently restrict individuals from possessing firearms in certain federal land units. Federal law should clarify that the second amendment rights of an individual in a unit of the National Park System or the National Wildlife Refuge System will not be infringed, preventing conflicts with State laws and protecting the right to keep and bear firearms. Federal law should protect the second amendment rights of individuals in National Park System and National Wildlife Refuge System units, allowing them to possess firearms and ammunition without federal restrictions based on their location. Federal law should protect second amendment rights in National Park System and National Wildlife Refuge System units, allowing possession of firearms and ammunition without federal restrictions based on location. The purpose of this section is to require hunting activities as a land use in all Federal land management plans unless clearly incompatible. The head of the agency must ensure hunting is allowed unless incompatible with the land's purposes, and reasons for not allowing hunting must be published in the management plan. Fees related to hunting activities on Federal land must be retained by the agency in charge to cover management costs directly linked to hunting on that land. Any fee exceeding the cost of land management is considered a restriction on hunting. The Act allows Federal agencies to retain fees from hunting activities on Federal land to cover management costs directly related to hunting. The definition of hunting includes hunting, trapping, netting, and fishing. This applies to all management plans developed, approved, or amended after the enactment of this section.
